1.text: Also these are Proverbs of Solomon, that men of Hezekiah king of Judah transcribed:—

2.text: The honour of God is to hide a thing, And the honour of kings to search out a matter.

3.text: The heavens for height, and the earth for depth, And the heart of kings—are unsearchable.

4.text: Take away dross from silver, And a vessel for the refiner goeth forth,

5.text: Take away the wicked before a king, And established in righteousness is his throne.

6.text: Honour not thyself before a king, And in the place of the great stand not.

7.text: For better that he hath said to thee, ‘Come thou up hither,’ Than that he humble thee before a noble, Whom thine eyes have seen.

8.text: Go not forth to strive, haste, turn, What dost thou in its latter end, When thy neighbour causeth thee to blush?

9.text: Thy cause plead with thy neighbour, And the secret counsel of another reveal not,

10.text: Lest the hearer put thee to shame, And thine evil report turn not back.

11.text: Apples of gold in imagery of silver, Is the word spoken at its fit times.

12.text: A ring of gold, and an ornament of pure gold, Is the wise reprover to an attentive ear.

13.text: As a vessel of snow in a day of harvest, So is a faithful ambassador to those sending him, And the soul of his masters he refresheth.

14.text: Clouds and wind, and rain there is none, Is a man boasting himself in a false gift.

15.text: By long-suffering is a ruler persuaded, And a soft tongue breaketh a bone.

16.text: Honey thou hast found—eat thy sufficiency, Lest thou be satiated with it, and hast vomited it.

17.text: Withdraw thy foot from thy neighbour’s house, Lest he be satiated with thee, and have hated thee.

18.text: A maul, and a sword, and a sharp arrow, Is the man testifying against his neighbour a false testimony.

19.text: A bad tooth, and a tottering foot, Is the confidence of the treacherous in a day of adversity.

20.text: Whoso is taking away a garment in a cold day, Is as vinegar on nitre, And a singer of songs on a sad heart.

21.text: If he who is hating thee doth hunger, cause him to eat bread, And if he thirst, cause him to drink water.

22.text: For coals thou art putting on his head, And Jehovah giveth recompense to thee.

23.text: A north wind bringeth forth rain, And a secret tongue—indignant faces.

24.text: Better to sit on a corner of a roof, Than with a woman of contentions, and a house of company.

25.text: As cold waters for a weary soul, So is a good report from a far country.

26.text: A spring troubled, and a fountain corrupt, Is the righteous falling before the wicked.

27.text: The eating of much honey is not good, Nor a searching out of one’s own honour—honour.

28.text: A city broken down without walls, Is a man without restraint over his spirit!
